channel.title: Guy shoots parents in head for taking halo 3 away
channel.description:
http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/7826663.stm Full story there.
His father Mark, who was shot in the head and survived, testified that his son came into the room and asked: "Would you guys close your eyes? I have a surprise for you." He said he expected a pleasant surprise. Then his head went numb from the gunshot.

mopman you say that on the pretence that they have actually read your previous posts

item.title: Guy shoots parents in head for taking halo 3 away
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

but any substance can be addictive, its all down to the chemical reactions it causes in the brain. Technically anything can be addictive as long as it releases the right chemicals in the brain. Alot of people get addicted to drugs because the of high, which then causes endorphines to be released into the brain because of their elated feelings towards the high

item.title: Guy shoots parents in head for taking halo 3 away
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:79, topic:256447”]Or we could use the original definition

[quote]
an addiction is a state in which the body relies on a substance for normal functioning and develops physical dependence, as in drug addiction.[/quote]

Although, admittedly, the DSM-IV now has “addiction without physiological dependance” listed. It didn’t though, until a recent revision.[/quote]

That old definition sweeps this case being an addiction of the table.

Read full topic
item.source: Guy shoots parents in head for taking halo 3 away

item.title: Guy shoots parents in head for taking halo 3 away
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Or we could use the original definition

an addiction is a state in which the body relies on a substance for normal functioning and develops physical dependence, as in drug addiction.

Although, admittedly, the DSM-IV now has “addiction without physiological dependance” listed. It didn’t though, until a recent revision.

item.source: Guy shoots parents in head for taking halo 3 away

item.title: Guy shoots parents in head for taking halo 3 away
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:77, topic:256447”]But thats not addiction. At least, not by the stricter definition of the word. That’s “I like to get high.”

Shrug.[/quote]

Well, i think you are mis-understanding the definition of addiction

The term "addiction" is used in many contexts to describe an obsession, compulsion, or excessive physical dependence or psychological dependence

the addiction we are talking about is psycological dependance, meaning that if the persons body comes to rely on this high, and if they do not get the high, then this will lead to psychological withdrawal symptoms (such as cravings, irritability, insomnia, depression, anorexia, etc).

Read full topic
item.source: Guy shoots parents in head for taking halo 3 away

item.title: Guy shoots parents in head for taking halo 3 away
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

Mopman:

Oh? How does that work exactly?

I can relate it in context to excersize,
Excersizing powerfully stimulates the adrenal glands causing a high. It also stimulates respiration and circulation, causing euphoric feelings related to these. It also produces lactic acid which can have a euphoric effect. It is this euphoric effect that i think sanga282 is talking about, i suppose it is the same as taking an extasy tablet, you get a high, like it and do it again. Addiction.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman

item.source: Guy shoots parents in head for taking halo 3 away

item.title: Guy shoots parents in head for taking halo 3 away
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:70, topic:256447”]Why don’t I get addicted to sex, wanking, eating good food and playing halo 3 then?

Of course things that are enjoyable involve neurotransmitters and endorphins and stuff, thats how enjoyment works. But comparing addiction/depedency or even non-addictive use of drugs that mess with these things to the normal use of them is absurd imo.

500mg of good base will flood your dopamine receptors a gazijillion* times over a good wank or a game of halo 3.

  • technical term.[/quote]
    you might not be addicted to endorphins, not everyone is but someone can be.

Read full topic
item.source: Guy shoots parents in head for taking halo 3 away

item.title: Guy shoots parents in head for taking halo 3 away
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Tico135, post:67, topic:256447”]If you truly think about it, the kid had problems, but it wasn’t just his fault. His parents allowed him to play the game, and allowed it to escalate to the situation that it did. By not limiting his play time in the beginning, they allowed their son to be addicted to a naturally violent game.

In regards to the kid shooting his parents, this again is at the fault of the parents. The key should not have been kept where the kid could find it, which is considered irresponsible. I believe the kid is responsible, and should face the full penalty. Everyone has a matter of self-control, if he was unable to control his anger, then he should be seeing someone about such problems.[/quote]

So you also think that McDonald’s is to blame when someone is obese? Globally seen it’s the same. Of course the parents have a little more control in the live of the kid then McDonald’s has over their customers.

And to the key part: How old is this kid? If your father/mother has a serious disease, which involves medication that is very bad for someone that doesn’t have this disease. They put the medicines in a closet, and lock it. You know where the key is. Are your parents to blame when you take this medicine and die?

Read full topic
item.source: Guy shoots parents in head for taking halo 3 away

item.title: Guy shoots parents in head for taking halo 3 away
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Why don’t I get addicted to sex, wanking, eating good food and playing halo 3 then?

Of course things that are enjoyable involve neurotransmitters and endorphins and stuff, thats how enjoyment works. But comparing addiction/depedency or even non-addictive use of drugs that mess with these things to the normal use of them is absurd imo.

500mg of good base will flood your dopamine receptors a gazijillion* times over a good wank or a game of halo 3.

  • technical term.

Read full topic

youve never heard of a gambling addiction? a sex addiction?
[/quote]

Nope. I’ve heard of habits, though. ;)[/quote]
lies, as i said before, these activites can release endorphins in the brain which make you crave that activity because you get addicted to the endorphins!

item.source: Guy shoots parents in head for taking halo 3 away

item.title: Guy shoots parents in head for taking halo 3 away
item.dc:creator: @Tico135 Tico
item.description:
@Tico135 wrote:

If you truly think about it, the kid had problems, but it wasn’t just his fault. His parents allowed him to play the game, and allowed it to escalate to the situation that it did. By not limiting his play time in the beginning, they allowed their son to be addicted to a naturally violent game.

In regards to the kid shooting his parents, this again is at the fault of the parents. The key should not have been kept where the kid could find it, which is considered irresponsible. I believe the kid is responsible, and should face the full penalty. Everyone has a matter of self-control, if he was unable to control his anger, then he should be seeing someone about such problems.

Read full topic
item.source: Guy shoots parents in head for taking halo 3 away
